author: mini_mads1980
title: Great Addition to a City Harbour
review:
Overview

Continuing the Ocean theme from Issue 29, this time we get a bright jet-ski.  Issue 30 was available between 12th August and 08th September 2020 with a UK price of £4.99.  This price covered the comic, the jet-ski and (for me) an additional Motorcycle Cop [952001] from Issue 23.  Others may have a different extra set.

Packet

The foil packet has a good image of Popstar Mike, waving as he powers the jet-ski though shark-infested waters.  Behind him is a quiet looking beach, with a large building that is probably a hotel.  As the set only has fifteen pieces you can clearly see what is in the packet.

On the back the 1:1 image is of the bright orange life jacket.

Minifigure

Popstar Mike is the main character for this edition of the Lego City Comic.  He is a good generic minifigure, that would look good in any beach set up.  Mike includes the torso with the surfer image on a blue / red vest, and is printed on both sides.

He is supposed to be a Popstar, which you won't guess at all from this set.  The inclusion of a microphone would have added to the story - or even the guitar he is seen playing on the poster that comes with the comic!  I understand the costs of using the signed photos that he hands out in the story (on 1X2 tiles) would have been too much for a set of this size and cost.

Mike is made up of the following parts:

  • Hair - Reddish Brown Mini Wig No 18 [6112609]
  • Head - Bright Yellow Mini Head No 1664 [6112623]
  • Torso - White Mini Upper Part No 1720 with Bright Yellow Arms [4612153]
  • Life Jacket - Bright Orange Mini Clothing No 9 [6231925]
  • Legs - Earth Blue Mini Lower Part [4162916]

The rarest part, Life Jacket, can be found in 12 sets to date.

Main Build / Parts

The jet-ski is a simple build, and probably slightly larger than you would expect to find in a comic set.  It is made from 10 parts and looks really good with the contrast of the colours used.  It takes no time at all to build, and is similar to lots that have gone before it.  However, it works well and has room to add a second minifigure should you wish, which adds to the play value.

Verdict

A vast improvement on the last offering, but still slight room for improvement based on the character in the comic.  As a standalone set it is fine how it is, and if you have a beach set up in your own city this will look perfect.  The cover price for the comic, and what is included is good value.

Up next in Issue 31 is a Fire Quad featuring Clemmons.
